title: Bill Finnegan
text:
William Robinson Finnegan (June 29, 1928 – November 28, 2008) was an American television and film producer whose well known credits included "<a href="The%20Fabulous%20Baker%20Boys">The Fabulous Baker Boys</a>", "<a href="Hawaii%20Five-O%20%281968%20TV%20series%29">Hawaii Five-O</a>" and the cult hit, "<a href="Reality%20Bites">Reality Bites</a>". he was a five time <a href="Emmy%20Awards">Emmy Awards</a> nominee.
Early life.
Bill Finnegan was born in <a href="Kansas%20City%2C%20Missouri">Kansas City, Missouri</a>, on June 29, 1928. He enlisted and served in the <a href="United%20States%20Navy">United States Navy</a> during <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>. Finnegan initially launched a career as a <a href="newsman">newsman</a> in 1950 when he began reporting for, among other publications, the "<a href="Associated%20Press">Associated Press</a>".
Television and film production.
Following a stint as a journalist and newsman, Finnegan began working as an <a href="assistant%20director">assistant director</a> and <a href="Unit%20production%20manager">production manager</a> in the television industry. Finnegan founded <a href="Finnegan-Pinchuk%20Company">Finnegan-Pinchuk</a>, a production company, with his wife, <a href="Patricia%20Finnegan">Patricia Finnegan</a>, and their <a href="business%20partner">business partner</a>, <a href="Sheldon%20Pinchuk">Sheldon Pinchuk</a>. Their company, headquartered in <a href="Studio%20City%2C%20California">Studio City, California</a>, became a supplier of <a href="network%20television">network</a> and <a href="cable%20television">cable</a> television movies by the late 1970s and 1980s.
Television productions by <a href="Finnegan-Pinchuk%20Company">Finnegan-Pinchuk</a> included <a href="Wes%20Craven">Wes Craven</a>'s "<a href="Stranger%20in%20Our%20House">Summer of Fear</a>" in 1978; "<a href="The%20Ordeal%20of%20Patty%20Hearst">The Ordeal of Patty Hearst</a>" (1979) starring <a href="Dennis%20Weaver">Dennis Weaver</a>; "<a href="The%20%245.20%20an%20Hour%20Dream">The $5.20 an Hour Dream</a>" with <a href="Linda%20Lavin">Linda Lavin</a> in 1980; 1982's "<a href="World%20War%20III%20%28miniseries%29">World War III</a>" starring <a href="Rock%20Hudson">Rock Hudson</a>; <a href="Jane%20Fonda">Jane Fonda</a>'s "<a href="The%20Dollmaker">The Dollmaker</a>" in 1984; "<a href="Amos%20%28film%29">Amos</a>", starring <a href="Kirk%20Douglas">Kirk Douglas</a> in 1985; "<a href="The%20Atlanta%20Child%20Murders%20%28TV%20miniseries%29">The Atlanta Child Murders</a>" with <a href="Morgan%20Freeman">Morgan Freeman</a>, also aired in 1985; "" which starred <a href="Tuesday%20Weld">Tuesday Weld</a> and <a href="River%20Phoenix">River Phoenix</a> in 1986, and "<a href="Hoover%20%28film%29">Hoover</a>" in 1987, which starred <a href="Treat%20Williams">Treat Williams</a>. Finnegan also produced several television shows, including "<a href="Hawaii%20Five-O%20%281968%20TV%20series%29">Hawaii Five-O</a>" in 1977 and "<a href="The%20Days%20and%20Nights%20of%20Molly%20Dodd">The Days and Nights of Molly Dodd</a>" ten years later in 1987, and the Emmy-award-winning <a href="Northern%20Exposure">Northern Exposure</a>, which aired from 1990 to 1995.
Finnegan and his company also produced or co-produced feature films including "<a href="Support%20Your%20Local%20Gunfighter">Support Your Local Gunfighter</a>" in 1971; "<a href="North%20Shore%20%281987%20film%29">North Shore</a>" in 1987; "<a href="The%20Fabulous%20Baker%20Boys">The Fabulous Baker Boys</a>" in 1989; "<a href="White%20Palace%20%28film%29">White Palace</a>" in 1990; "<a href="The%20Babe">The Babe</a>" in 1992; "<a href="CrissCross">CrissCross</a>" in 1992; "<a href="Reality%20Bites">Reality Bites</a>", starring <a href="Ben%20Stiller">Ben Stiller</a>, in 1994; and "<a href="Ed%20%28film%29">Ed</a>", starring <a href="Matt%20LeBlanc">Matt LeBlanc</a>, in 1996. Finnegan officially retired from the production business in 2003.
Death.
Bill Finnegan died of <a href="Parkinson%27s%20disease">Parkinson's disease</a> at his home in <a href="Sag%20Harbor%2C%20New%20York">Sag Harbor, New York</a>, on November 28, 2008, at the age of 80. He and his wife, Patricia Finnegan, had four children – Michael Finnegan, a political reporter for the "<a href="Los%20Angeles%20Times">Los Angeles Times</a>"; <a href="William%20Finnegan">William Finnegan</a>, a staff reporter for "<a href="The%20New%20Yorker">The New Yorker</a>"; Colleen, a doctor; and Kevin, a labor lawyer.
